Blog.post: Last night I seriously over booked myself. I really need to pay more attention to what I agree to. Work from 8 - 5, which ran an hour late. Rush home and change. I was invited to go to Kayla's new schools Fall Fling carnival. Kayla is my 6 year old neighbor and she is just one of the cutest kids. Her brother, John, will be 2 in January. I am lucky enough that their parents, Tina and Pete, let me play with them. We moved here when he was only a couple of weeks old and it has been a blast watching them both grow and change. Mark and I both totally adore them. I view it as my duty to make sure that little boys know it is bad to make her cry :o). I had a GREAT time with Kayla and John and the carnival. She was running around telling kids and their parents that I was her friend and I had a real motorcycle. She always makes me feel like a hero. I didn't get home from there until 9:00 so I came home, changed jackets, and was off to my kickboxing school's Halloween party. Another great group of people. everyone is treated like family. Standard greeting is a hug and kiss on the cheek. Can't help but feeling at home with this group. I started kickboxing about 3 weeks ago now. It is great! Good exercise, good fun, and I get to beat people up twice a week. You can't beat that! I didn't get back to the house again until 11:00 so I decided to stay home. I felt kind of bad. I had wanted to go to my friend Creech's birthday/Halloween party. His parties are always great with a biarre mix of people. Just going to people watch is a blast. I just wasn't in the mood to haul my cookies up to Redwood City for it. This afternoon I helped Tina get party favors and such made up for Kayla's Hallowen party tomorrow afternoon. I had blown two hours before I knew it. It is nice having another chick around to gab with. Everyone I know are guys. Never really got along with chicks much. I always tell her it's great she had kids. I can play with hers, have all the fun, and no need to be having my own yet :o). Tomorrow I will probably go over and help finish the decorations and help with the party. Looks like she will have around 40 kids! She throws the coolest kid parties. I am jealous. Never had stuff that cool when I was a kid. Then again, everything kids have now is a lot cooler than what I remember there being. Watch this spot for updates. I will try to get better at writing and keep pretty regular updates. Julz

A few months ago I crashed at Thunderhill. At the time it appeared all I had done was get a small concussion and bruis my left arm a bit. Well, the shoulder never stopped bugging me and all the Aleve and Advil in the world wasn't helping. When I started kickboxing a few weeks ago it really started bugging me. I finally broke down and saw an Orthopedic doctor. Her diagnosis, a strained rotator cuff. Her solution, six weeks of physical therapy twice a week and some heavy duty anti-inflamatory drugs. My thoughts on the whole thing, YUCK. I went to my first PT appointment yesterday having no idea what to expect. The doc there is pretty cool and I like him. He did some tests to isolate exactly where the injury was and decide what to do about it. Then he came back with a big book full of excellent illustratioins of everything under your skin. Turns out I have damaged a tendon that is part of a cluster of muscles and tendons that make up the rotator cuff around your shoulder. Don't ask me the name, I can't remember. It goes inbetween bones and isusually an exact fit. If it swells up due to injury then whammo! You have what I got, pain. Constant, annoying, degrees of pain. I am thinking I am going to have to do a mess of boring exercises and all. Nope! I get to sit there. Now this is physical therapy! They put two types of warm goop all over my shoulder and then do this heated ultra sound thing. Mmmmmm, very nice. Then they top it off with a few minutes of the worlds largest, coldest ice pack. Totally ruins the whole relaxing ultrasound thing. Going by the restrictions they gave me I may as well just tie the arm off. No lifting anything over a pound or two with my left arm. No moving my arm over shoulder level. This is going to make sleeping hard. My arms are always over my head. No carrying things with my left arm. He started to say something about not riding so much but then he just smiled and said to stay light on the bars and lean on my tank bag :o). At least he understands. He also didn't say I had to stop kickboxing. Of course, I didn't exactly ask either. Classic case of "don't ask, don't tell". Mark has managed to come down with a wicked little cold. I think the sudden weather change caught him. Poor guy is quite miserable. His band, Moxie Rox, (http://www.moxierox.com) will be playing their first public show November 2. I am really proud of him. He plays so well and he has so much fun. The whole band is pretty cool. More later!

Halloween was a blast! Mark and I had both forgotten to get candy all week and so we both ran in a grabbed a bunch on the way home form work. We ended up with some 10 or 12 bags of candy. Mark was looking around at the neighbors and decided we had to do something or we would be lame. We grabbed one of the FZR400's that was in a state of disassembly and laid it down on the lawn. Then we stuck a light under it to give it that spooky bike wreck look. The we tossed the plastics from the bike around the lawn. The candy was put in this huge bucket we use to put kegs on ice in and we had so much it was filled half way up. I put a big sign on the bucket that said "CANDY" and put the bucket towards the top of the bike wreck. Mark dug out his messed up leathers and his messed up helmet from his big crash at Buttonwillow and put it all on. I took some red food dye and we smeared it on his leathers like blood so he looked pretty gross. Then he went and laid on the lawn with his head near the bucket. Even the adults weren't sure or were positive it was a stuffed dummy! Mark spent the evening laying on the lawn and making boys and girls, young and old scream. We managed to give away almost all of that candy and he had a blast. Pictures will be posted soon. Watch this space for a link. Tomorrow night is the big night for Moxie Rox. I am looking forward to it. I am getting kind of old now so I am gonna have to take a nap Saturday afternoon or I will end up falling asleep during the show. We will be out well past my bed time. Plus I am pretty sore from kickboxing class. I got to graple for the first time Wednesday night. It is a Jujitsu thing and a lot of fun. It is kinda like wrestling. I started laughing after class. We graple pretty rough. You could tell by all the hair on the mat from everyone in the class.

I have two words... FLU SUCKS! I feel like a giant snot factory with no temperature control on the thermostat. Just what is up with the cough that accompanies this years flavor of flu? Non-friggin stop!

Random things to catch everyone up. Mark is in another band! They've been together less than a year, but more than six months. Check out their website at http://www.moxierox.com . Since getting together with Moxie Rox Mark has aquired a great deal more instruments and built a very cool digital studio in one of the rooms of the house. He went from having two electric guitars and one acoustic to three electric guitars, one bass guitar, one acoustic, a home built electronic drum kit, and keyboard. He's even been making some original tunes that sound really good! If you are in the San Jose area mark Saturday, November 2nd, on your calendars. Moxie Rox will be performing live and in public at The Fifth Quarter, 1373 Kooser, San Jose, at 9:30pm. This will be their first public performance. Up until now they have only been doing private parties. Hope to see everyone there! Isn't funny how you can fly from India to San Jose in one day but a postcard you sent from India won't arrive in San Jose until 12 days after you do? Thanks for the postcard Charles! Whenever someone I know travels oversea's I always ask them to steal me something. The rules are that it cannot be purchased and must have country or city name on it. I have gotten some fascinating things this way. I have a whole collection of ill gotten booty from around the world. My most recent was a really neat bottle opener from the Taj hotel in India. The thief broke the must not purchase rule and also brought me home some beautiful silver jewelery from the market in Chennai, India. I couldn't be mad though. It is beautiful and it feels good to know I am thought of. They moved the entire IT group, (all 6 of us), into another area this week. It bites. Instead of having a real cube with real walls I am now stuck in a bullpen. Oops, I am sorry. It is a "think tank" configuration. You know, te configuration that makes sure everybody is in your business. I spend my whole day with my phone headset over one ear and my finger in the other. No walls, means everybody gets to hear everyone else's conversations. Whether we want to or not. I am not happy. I have always hated bullpens. They make people act weird. Like your desk is a common area. Something a couple of little walls prevent. Oh well, more later. Julz

Today was a great day. Woke up late, laid around, showered, and then went across the street to help decorate for Kayla's Halloween party. Came home for a bit and made some grub for Mark and I was back to the neighbors to help out with the party. Wow! A lot of kids. I lost track of how many. I know that a great deal of food was eaten, drinks were drank, and fun was had by all. We put tons of tose temporary stick on tattoo's on loads of kids. We got soaked bobbing for apples. A Spiderman pinata was broken and children dove for candy and prizes. There were so many great costumes. The kids were just adorable. I put blue and red stripes in Kayla's hair and she looked great! I am home now, with a load of junk food, and very tired. They can really wear you out. Mark's day wasn't as good. He has a horrible cough that is keeping both of us up at night, a miserable headache, and is producing enough snot to fill a bathtub. He was supposed to go to rehearsal today but couldn't make it. Poor guy. I really hate it when he's sick. I always feel so inadequate because there is so little I can do about it. The good news is that I haven't got whatever he has yet. Usually I manage to come down with everything he gets in no time flat. I may actually beat it this time though. I am getting tired of sharing diseases with him. Julz

So, due to families deciding to get married and travel great distances and such Mark and I will be staying home for Thanksgiving. Since we decided to stay home but still wanted a huge turkey dinner we are having one :o). This year we have invited a few friends over and I am gonna cook a huge amount of food. Then we are going to live on left overs for the next week or two. Margaritas and turkey will be the key words for the day! There was just no way I was going to Mom's for Thanksgiving then driving home, then 4 days later going back to Mom's for my cousins wedding. Speaking of cousins weddings I am just about to be the last hold out among us. Eight cousins and by the end of this year it looks like out of us there will be only 2 left by the end of the year who have chosen to remain unmarried. Gads it makes me feel old. I remember when I thought my oldest cousins were gods and then when I thought they were just dinosaurs. They are so much older than me they've always been the big kids. Of course, that made me the bratty tag along cousin. Playing with me wa s a chore you had to do at holiday gatherings. They must have done ok. I can't remember them ever being mean to me. Except for that whole glow in the dark scorpion under the bed thing. To this day I get the creeps walking in a dark room with a bed in it.

Today sux. The more I do my job, the more I hate it. I am truly sick of people who lack the common sense nature gave a jellyfish and insist that you know nothing. Well if you know so stinkin' much why are you calling me to fix your friggin' problem?!? Oh, and why is English so friggin' hard to speak?!? Gads, I spend half my day trying not to make a cultural faux paux with some of the end users. It's stupid. You're in the USA! Get used to OUR ways. We behave according to your ways in your country. What's so damn hard about dealing with our ways in our country? The bullpen is hell. I spend my whole day whispering and trying to look busy when I have nothing to do. I have cleaned and reorganized my space more times than I can count. You hear EVERYthing in here and everyone else hears EVERYthing you are up to. If a fly farts we all hear it. I am at a point where I will cry tears of joy when I lose this job. Make no mistake, I will lose this job. It's only a matter of time before they have more lay off's and I am only one of three people left from the contract company they use. They have decided to no longer supply cell phones to end users which eliminates one more thing I was in charge of. We don't order any parts or PC's anymore so I have nothing to do there. Soon they will eliminate pagers as well. I am also in direct line of sight of the Director of I.T. so I am forced to look terribly busy even when it is painfully slow. I knew my days here were numbered as soon as they moved our butts into this friggin' bullpen. It's one thing to know people are keeping an eye on you. That's normal business. This really stinks though. To feel the hot breath of the "your position is being eliminated" dragon every day, every hour, is just wrong. Having a crappy job I can deal with. Not having a job at all I can deal with. Waiting to not have a job is just too much. ARRRGGGHH!!!! Julz

I know, I know. I have been neglecting my blog for a few days. I promise to sit down and update this thing for the few people who actually read it this week. There just hasn't been muhc to say and a whole lot to do. Julz
Today I drug my butt out of bed at 9:00am and went to take my test for my yellow belt. I passed!!

Woohoo! Change of plans. Did a little checking and I can get both classes I need online for my two associates degree's. Registration was sent this week for Economics at Hancock College and Business Communications at DeAnza College. So by summer I will be a college graduate. Then I can complete my computer science associates and transfer to a university for a bachelors degree in that. Let's just hope it doesn't take as long as my associates. I try to do all my classes online now thru the distance learning offered. I get much better grades when attendance isn't required and I can do things my way, on my time, and my learning style. I never have done well with the standard way of education. Can't sit still for it and all that damn group interaction crap annoys me. Most people seem to run at a slower speed and less organized fashion than I do. Group activites annoy me. Forced group activites piss me off and I tend to fight them to my disadvantage. If I want to interact, I will. If I don't want to and you make me, everyone around me pays. I tend to make everyone around me as miserable as I am. Not a good idea but I can't seem to stop myself. I expect one day I will outgrow this but at almost 32 years old I doubt it.

Last night I did a practice test for my kickboxing. Sifu says I should pass no problem. I am still kind of nervous. I am not real comfortable being watched yet when I kickbox. I got brave and asked Mark to come to my test anyway. There will be quite a few people there and while you test they are all staring at you. So by Saturday afternoon I should be a yellow belt kickboxer. One more day and I get a whole week off of work! I will be pretty busy though. My house is a mess. I have some serious house cleaning to do. I would be so embarrassed if my house was not pristine for all my guests. Gotta do a bunch of child proofing to. I would hate for the kids to get into something they shouldn't. More later... Julz

Not much to say. I have been working a lot of over time trying to pad my paycheck. I am going to get laid off the week before Christmas. I am not supposed to know that. Mark and I updated my resume last night and I started circulating it. If I am lucky I will land something. If I am just another casulty of the Silicon Valley then I may take more then one class in the Spring. I am now two classes away from two Associates degree's. I mailed in my registration for one class this week. It is gonna be hard. Economics has never been my strong suit. After that I will register for Business Communications and I will be an official college grad! It only took 12 years! Oy. Kickboxing is going great! I have lost 10 pounds and I test for my yellow belt this Saturday. I am very excited about it. The Thanksgiving plans are coming together nicely. I am pretty nervous about cooking a meal for 13 people, including my Mom. The good news is that she will be here to help so I won't screw anything up. Mom makes the worlds best turkey gravy. I drool just thinking about it. Mark is still wishing he had any job but the one he has. The new Controller is just a dork who apparently does little to nothing. The band has a booking agent now. She was VERY impressed with their CD. Looks like I may become a bar fly soon supporting Mark at shows. They are very good and I am very proud of him. He is a lot of fun to watch play and if you get the chance you should come see them when they perform. That's about it for now. I will try to write something more comprehensive this weekend. Julz

So after Mark's visit to the Emergency Room and lots of rest and drugs he was getting better. Then this morning WHAMMY! He is back to where he started and back to the doc he goes. This time to a specialist. Looks like I am off to my cousins wedding alone this weekend. No way he can ride and sitting up that long in the truck is just asking for misery. Should be a good weekend though. Saturday morning before the wedding I am going to take an easy ride with a friend back home. She just got her first bike recently and is loving it. Oh well, more later.

So I thought having the week off would be great. Boy was I wrong. I get more rest at the office. At least here there were no people to bug me with questions that simple common sense could have answered. I have learned that common sense is a rare commodity in the human race. Saturday I got my yellow belt. Mark went to watch me test. Spending 3 hours of boredom only to see my 5 minutes of fame sure made me feel good. Spent the rest of the day doing a bit of cleaning and preparing the shopping list for Thanksgiving. Sunday I did a minor bit of cleaning and a major bit of sleeping. One day I will have to expound on the wonder of sleeping for hours and hours. Sometimes I wish I could go back to my teen years and the days of sleeping so much I would miss and entire 24 hours of the world around me. It was wonderful. The older I get, the more I love sleeping, the less I seem to be able to get. Baically I woke up long enough to put the groceries away and make a list of the things I needed to actually go to the store for. Should be fun. I haven't seen the inside of a grocery store in months. I despise shopping of any sort. The internet is the best place to shop. I can do it in my underwear and not even brush my hair. No traffic, no "special" people, no annoying clerks with their movement gears set at slow and slower, and no old ladies blocking aisles while they summon the ability to make a friggin decision. Monday I slept in, cleaned some more, did the final shopping, ran off to physical therapy and my first class as a yellow belt. Physical therapy went well as usual. Kickboxing had a problem. One of the first things I get to learn is falling. Essentially you hurl your body at the ground in one of four prescribed methods. The idea is to do it properly so it does not hurt. Umm, well, this takes practice. First thing I learned is that my shoulder is not ready to be hurled at the ground in two of the methods. How did I learn such a thing so quickly you ask? Simple, I hurled my body to the ground and an intense pain went through my shoulder, arm, and neck. I figure this is a one time thing. Being the brilliant person I am I decide to give it a couple or three more tries. So, as my Mom says. "She has to learn things the hard way". I spent the next 45 minutes working on the two falls I could do and feelling the growing, pulsating pain in my shoulder telling me the swelling will be impressive by the time I get home. Most of the time I say pain is just weakness leaving the body. I think I need a secondary saying. Something like pain is your bodies way of informing you that you are stupid and it will make you pay. Tuesday I slept in. Starting to see a pattern here? Shoulder was not happy, which was making me unhappy and of course I had to spread the joy :o). It was also pie day number one. My first unsupervised adventure into making pies useing Mom's recipe's. If they don't taste good I will die. Made two apple pies. Dang near stopped after peeling a few apples and headed out to Bed, Bath, & Beyond to buy and apple corer/peeler. It took me forever just to get the apples peeled, cut, and flavored. I can see why people prefer to buy pies rather than make them from scratch. Scratch may taste better but who on earth would do this all the time?!? Mark came home, told me that days act of idiocy by the morons at his office and ran off to rehearsal. Moxie Rox has added something like 26 new songs to their list and are trying to get them all down before the show at Fibber McGee's, December 27. Wednesday I freaked out. I had a ton of cleaning to do, two more pies to make, a run to Hickory Farms, an appointment with the orthopod, physical therapy and my Mom would be arriving around dinner time. So the first thing I did was nothing. Then I took apple pie number two to the office for the guys who were stuck there during the shut down. What they didn't know is they were my testers. I didn't want to go feeding people at my house an unknown so who better to use for a food poisoning check then co-workers :o). All was well, smiles all around, and nobody puked. Life is good, pies are a go. Ran home and began the pies, ran off mid-pie to the orthopods, back to pies, stuff in oven, run to Hickory Farms, cancel physical therapy appointment, finish pies, inform Mark I have earned sushi for dinner and he is the one to buy it. Orthopod is happy with my progress. She says I will probably take two or three more months to heal though. She is under the silly idea I am active, hard to tie down, and use my arms a lot. Ok, so she's right. All pies came out well but one. The one that didn't come out well still tasted damn good though. It just didn't set up right so it was more like lemon soup than pie. So, I used a spoon instead of a fork to eat it. I decided Hickory Farms needed a whole paragraph of its own. Where I grew up Hickory Farms was a treat. A VERY tasty treat. I could live on the beef stick and cheesballs alone for months. You waited all year for Hickory Farms. The store would show up in the mall a week or two before Thanksgiving and be gone by New Years Day. You had to get all you could while it was available. When I moved up to the Bay Area and discovered they have stores in malls here all year long I was in heaven! Woohoo! Hickory Farms whenever I wanted it. Man, this city livin' might be ok after all. Any place that has Hickory Farms all year can't be all bad ya'know. It only took me a few months to get to a point of ot even wanting to look at the stuff. Now I am back to waiting faithfully all year for my Hickory Farms. This year I splurged. I bought the large beef stick and three different cheeses. Now all I have to do is wait for my Christmas See's Candy box of nuts n' chews and my year will be complete. On to Thursday and the adventures of Thanksgiving. I wake up to the sounds of some serious pain and it isn't me. Fifteen minutes later I am in the truck driving Mark to the Good Samaritan emergency room where he is given two shots, and perscribed three bottles of pills. I am freaking out. I got a bird that needs to be stuffed and put in the oven. Call Mom, who accuses Mark of faking and says she is sure we are at Denny's having breakfast so I can get out of getting the bird in the oven. Thank goodness for Moms. She got the bird all stuffed and in the oven for me. Now I am all off schedule though and it is gonna get worse. I am freaked enough about cooking my first Thanksgiving meal for 12 to 15 people and now my perfectly planned schedule is out the window. Turns out Mark is having some kind of serious muscle spasm thing that hurts like hell. I remember when he had to take me to the ER for the same thing and hurts like hell is quite an understatment. Problem is they sent him home with a perscription for three bottles of pills, it is Thanksgiving Day, and I need to find an open pharmacy before the shots wear off. I also still have several side dishes and appetizers to prepare. I call around and the nearest open pharmacy is a Walgreens 15 miles away. I jump on the bike and break land speed records getting there. The only open pharmacy for 15 miles, I should have known would be packed and badly under staffed. I spent more time in line then I did getting there and back. I figure give them the perscriptions, wander around store for 20 minutes trying not to do any impulse buying, pick up drugs, go home. BZZZZT! Wrong! They tell me it is gonna be one and a half to two hours. Did I mention I am in a really crappy part of San Jose where being a white girl on an expensive, pretty, motorcycle is not exactly ideal? Home I go to get the side dishes prepared. Side dishes mostly ready and back to the pharmacy in Timbuktu for more fun with the mentally challenged. You ever get the impression some people are exactly in their place in life? Finally everything is going well, on schedule, Mark is drugged and I am feeding him alcohol to give it an extra kick. I am thinking I might even get a shower. Well, it was a thought. Guests started arriving and now I am stuck with my unshowered look. The good news is it went great. The food was just like I remembered it when I was a kid. Everyone seemed to like it and all had a good time. I also now know the limit on dinner parties. I almost ran out of plates and serving dishes! It was great having my Mom and all of our friends. Friday Mom went with Tina, our neighbor from across the street, to the Harvest Festival craft show at the convention center and I cleaned up after Thanksgiving. It only took four loads in the dishwasher and all was done. Mark was still quite uncomfortable and could only sit up for a few minutes at a time before it hurt too much. I finally got my shower much to everyone's pleasure. Saturday we all laid around all day. Mom and I went to the craft store on Union for a bit but didn't see much. Sunday I slept in, woke up to see Mom off, and have spent this day dreading going to work tomorrow. REMINDER: Moxie Rox will be playing at Fibber McGee's in Sunnyvale, Friday, December 27.

News on Mark. Doc says he has a couple of compressed discs. Now he gets to take prednizone . I am a little nervous about him taking that medication. My Mom had to take it when I was a kid and the side affects were severe psychosis and depression. Essentially I spent all my time trying to be the little mommy and cook dinners for us and dad and keep my little brother out of firing range. She went nuts, literally. It had to be awful for her. Being a kid that was not what I was thinking about at the time though. I was learning how to cook... FAST. Good thing it was during the summer or I would have never been able to get my brother and I off to school and fed and everything else. Anyway, looks like Mark will slowly get better and I will be watching closely for psychosis.

Went to my cousins wedding over the weekend. It was very nice and Trish, his new wife, was just beautiful. Now matter how nice a service it is weddings always bore me to tears. I simply do no have the attention span for it. It didn't help being there alone in the sea of coupledom. I had to fend off all the "when are you getting married", "is he your finance yet", "I was sure you were engaged" crap on my own. I started getting a bit sarcastic and almost crude with my replies. They kept me entertained though. I bolted for the door as soon as etiquette allowed. Not much fun hanging out, alone, realizing you are a middle generation cousin, with nobody to hang out with. Everyone was either 15 years older or 15 years younger than me. At 31 I am just to big for the kids table and to young to sit with the adults. I still wouldn't have missed it though. I got to see people I haven't seen in years and it was fun to show them me, all grown up, and not knocked up in prison. I have been to a lot of weddings, added up a rough estimate of the bill in head, and made a decision. I am not going to bore anyone with all that nor will I start my life out with someone in debt over a ceremony. It seems so stupid to me. One of two things will happen if I ever get married. My Mom will get a phone call and be told to either get on a plane to Vegas or get in the truck and get to San Jose. I will put on my clean jeans and a nice shirt and we will do what needs to be done in the shortest ceremony known to mankind. A short time later I will throw a pot luck BBQ where we can all get drunk and eat cake. No debt, no ceremony to sit through for the beer and cake reward. I can't sit still through a five minute cartoon and have been known to wear a walkman at funerals just so I don't fidget so I don't expect anyone else to try and sit still thorugh mine. Heck, I don't expect I could sit still through mine. Yawning while the judge is yakking on and on at your own wedding would not look good and I haven't figured a way to hide a walkman :o). So, Mom and I bolted from the wedding and then headed off to a little shin dig that a co-worker was throwing. Once again I get to amaze people with the all grown up version of Julz. I must have been hella wild when I was a teen. A lot of the people my Mom works with are teachers that have known me since jr.high. The cool thing is it is all the teachers I remember liking and I always love to see them. I figure a student as an adult, or as adul as I get, is the product that a teacher strives for and really never gets to see the end result of. So I get to see them, and they get to see that they made a difference. It works for me anyway. We hung out there for about 30 or 45 minutes and then headed home. I sat around the house foir a bit and decided to call Nici and see how she was doing. Might as well try to see some friends before I haul my cookies another 260 miles back to San Jose. Nothing like cramming 500 miles, a wedding, a party, and visit with friends all into 24 hours. Ended up hanging at Nici's until midnight and then back to Mom's for some sleep. Sunday I woke up, went by grams house, and headed for home. It is a long boring superslab ride. So I try to make a time trial out of it. Best time is two hours and thirty minutes and that included a fuel stop! One of these days I am going to get so arrested. Monday Mark went in for his MRI. He will have the results Wednesday when he see's his doc. Watch this spot for an update.

So Mark is doing much better now. He is feelling good enough to over do it a bit though and is making himself sore. I am sure in another week or so he will be starting physical therapy. He still can't ride and it's going to be a while before he can. I don't think the truck has ever been driven so much. He is able to play his guitar more now and that is making him happy. Antisocial A common misconception is that antisocial personality disorder refers to people who have poor social skills. The opposite is often the case. Instead, antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a lack of conscience. People with this disorder are prone to criminal behavior, believing that their victims are weak and deserving of being taken advantage of. They tend to lie and steal. Often, they are careless with money and take action without thinking about consequences. They are often agressive and are much more concerned with their own needs than the needs of others. Obsessive-Compulsive Obsessive-Compulsive personality disorder is similar to obsessive-compulsive anxiety disorder. People with this disorder are overly focused on orderliness and perfection. Their need to do everything "right" often interferes with their productivity. They tend to get caught up in the details and miss the bigger picture. They set unreasonably high standards for themselves and others, and tend to be very critical of others when they do not live up to these high standards. They avoid working in teams, believing others to be too careless or incompetent. They avoid making decisions because they fear making mistakes and are rarely generous with their time or money. They often have difficulty expressing emotion. Histrionic People with histrionic personality disorder are constant attention seekers. They need to be the center of attention all the time, often interrupting others in order to dominate the conversation. They use grandiose language to discribe everyday events and seek constant praise. They may dress provacatively or exaggerate illnesses in order to gain attention. They also tend to exaggerate friendships and relationships, believing that everyone loves them. They are often manipulative. Narcissistic Narcissistic personality disorder is characterized by self-centeredness. Like histrionic disorder, people with this disorder seek attention and praise. They exaggerate their achievements, expecting others to recongize them as being superior. They tend to be choosy about picking friends, since they believe that not just anyone is worthy of being their friend. They tend to make good first impressions, yet have difficulty maintaining long-lasting relationships. They are generally uninterested in the feelings of others and may take advantage of them. Avoidant Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by extreme social anxiety. People with this disorder often feel inadequate, avoid social situations, and seek out jobs with little contact with others. They are fearful of being rejected and worry about embarassing themselves in front of others. They exaggerate the potential difficulties of new situations to rationalize avoiding them. Often, they will create fantasy worlds to substitute for the real one. Unlike schizoid personality disorder, avoidant people yearn for social relations yet feel they are unable to obtain them. They are frequently depressed and have low self-confidence.

It aches all the time and sometimes hurts so bad I consider going to the emergency room to beg for demerol or morphine. In October 2002 I decided to see and orthopedic doctor for it. I figured if it wasn't better by then there must be something wrong. What I got mostly was lip service. The doc pretty much pat me on the head and sent me out the door with a pescription for Celebrex and an appointment for physical therapy. So, 12 weeks of physical therapy go by and I never really noticed a diference. I was in no mood to go back to a doc who explained nothing and gave me no options. So here I am, a year later. Shoulder still hurts. Last week I went three days trying not to move it at all it was hurting so bad. A friend recommends a doc and I figure I got nothing to lose so I will give this new doc a try. He has explained a lot, he has given me options, he started today with the easiest option. The man shot me up full of cortizone and tells me I will be a bit sore for a few hours. What he should of said was hold on to your hat girl, you're gonna me miserable. What is it with docs always down playing shit? I was prepared for being a little achy tonight. I was not prepared for don't touch me, don't talk to me, I want my Mommy miserable. Have you ever gotten a cortizone shot? It is just plain weird. They use a considerably large needle and I am talking not just long but dang the thing is thick! They give you a mix of cortizone and lidocane so it goes kinda numb and doesn't hurt right away. It goes in like a boulder and feels like it is gonna explode out of your skin! Later you find you have this nice 2 inch diameter purple bruise where they stuck that huge ol' needle in. Anyways, doc says this may not help at all, this may fix the problem forever, or this may only work for a few weeks. I need to call him and gove weekly reports. Depending on what the results are, I might get an MRI. The most invasive thing that may or may not happen is they go in and carve off a piece of the bone. Gads I hope this does the trick. Although I would probably get a really cool scar out of it. :o)

He and his co-worker/buddy dave got the wild idea to go north, to Ugene, Oregon and back for this ride. Brave, brave, men they are. There is a reason why birds go south in the winter. Anyway, north they went. Shortly outside of the Bay Area they met rain. Then they spent the next 14 hours in it. Gear soaked completely through, cold as cold gets, they kept going. I would have come home. They made it as far as Medford, Oregon and had a short visit with Marks Aunt and Uncle. At that point they decided north sucked. They would head back south and then over shoot San Jose and back track to make up for the 200 miles they lost not going to Ugene. I sat at home all day waiting for the phone to ring. With the weather like it was I needed regular check ins from Mark so I knew all was ok. What I didn't realize is that I would also sit up all night waiting for those same phone calls. Those poor guys were gonna get rained on again. At 6:30am Mark called me from Salinas, they had gotten a little over 1000 miles done in 24 hours. So I guess you're all wondering how the interview went. One word, bizarre. It's the first time in my life I had a great time. Genentech has really come up with an amazing and fun way to evaluate potential employee's. There were about 15 of us there hoping to fill one of three open positions. They broke us up into three groups and put an observer at each table. There were also wandering observers and the moderator of the group interview observing us. It was kind of weird knowing that evrything you say and do was being analyzed. Not knowing exactly what they were looking for made it a bit hard on the nerves though. We were given several types of tasks that we had to work on as a group and then one person would present to the class. Kinda like school, but with higher stakes. Six of us will be notified sometime near the end of next week that we made it to round two. So if I make it to round two, I have a 50/50 chance of making it in. I think I did well with the group exercises. I don't think I did so well on the written part. We were given a packet containing five essay questions and three semi-mathmatical questions. I am sure I blew the math part. I spent an hour on those things and finally just gave it my best educated guess. At the end of it all they fed us pizza and soda pops. Never had an interview where they fed you at the end, or at all. Even if it was five hours or more. So, I am not holding out hope for anything. I am in no shape to deal with getting my hopes up and having it all go down the toilet again. It sure would be nice though. It is one heck of a great company to work for.

Wish me luck! Tomorrow morning I will be spending five miserable hours busting my ass to impress the hell out of hiring managers at Genentech. It is one of the best places to work. I have never heard of anyone who didn't like the place. I have actually been studying for this interview I want it so bad. I am not stupid though. I am not expecting anything and I am not even going to hope.

Nuclear Plant Looks for Missing Parts Thu Apr 22,12:43 PM ET Add U.S. National - AP to My Yahoo! By WILSON RING, Associated Press Writer MONTPELIER, Vt. - Engineers at a Vermont nuclear plant searched Thursday for two missing pieces of a highly radioactive fuel rod while experts acknowledged they may never be found. The operators of the Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant reported the missing pieces Wednesday, saying they were not where they were supposed to be in the large pool used to store fuel rods. One of the missing pieces is about the size of a pencil. The other is about as thick but is 17 inches long. The spent fuel rods are highly radioactive and would be fatal to anyone who came in contact with them without being properly shielded, Nuclear Regulatory Commission spokesman Neil Sheehan said. Spent nuclear fuel could be used by terrorists to construct so-called dirty bombs that would spread deadly radiation with conventional explosives. "We do not think there is a threat to the public at this point. The great probability is this material is still somewhere in the pool," Sheehan said. The pieces could also have been sent years ago to a testing laboratory or a low-level nuclear waste disposal facility. The pieces were part of a fuel rod that was removed in 1979 from the Vermont Yankee reactor, which is currently shut down for refueling and maintenance. The pool where used fuel rods are stored is 40 feet deep and contains 2,789 fuel assemblies. The pencil-thin fuel rods are 12 feet long and filled with uranium pellets. Sheehan said that the missing pieces might have been cut from longer rods for testing or could have broken when they were removed from the fuel assemblies. The search for the missing pieces was going to include the use of a remote controlled camera in the pool as well as review of the documents dating back decades that cover shipments and movements of radioactive material. Sheehan cited the heightened awareness of the need to control nuclear material that followed the Sept. 11 terror attacks. "We don't want this falling into the wrong hands," he said. "This is something we would never take lightly." Gov. James Douglas, after speaking Wednesday afternoon with the head of the NRC, said he was "very concerned" about the missing fuel at the plant, run by Entergy Nuclear. "This situation is intolerable," he said. In 2002 a Connecticut nuclear plant was fined $288,000 after a similar loss. That fuel was never accounted for. Vermont Yankee is located in the southeastern town of Vernon, on the state lines with Massachusetts and New Hampshire. The state's Public Safety Department and Homeland Security Unit also were notified of the missing fuel.

So here is the update of the year. Saturday morning I went to test for my blue belt. When my turn to test came I was really excited and pumped. Ready to really show how hard I had studied and practiced. I was gonna look friggin' awesome. I started out strong and was looking pretty good. Then it happened. I tried a spinning back kick and I screwed up BIG TIME. I made the biggest mistake you could make. I was focusing on the kick itself so it would look perfect and did not give my foot positions enough attention. I planted my left foot. When I spun, everything above my left knee spun, everything below it did not. I spun right into the floor and screamed like a little girl. It was the most instantaneous and unbelievable pain I have ever felt. Mostly I was just damn scared. When it happened there was a VERY loud pop. Several people heard it. Then it felt like something was tried to shoot out the side of my knee. I a panicked a little. After about a minute or two I got the pain was gone and I got a grip on myself. My first thought was "I don't want to drive a car". Then all I could really feel was disappointed. I was really looking forward to showing Sifu and Sihing how well they had taught me. I had studied and praticed so hard. I was also feeling bad about scaring everyone. I was picked up off the floor and discovered that even the slightest weight on my left leg and my knee would buckle. I can't walk. I can hop on one foot though! Hopped off the floor, got myself together, and hopped to my bike. It took a bit of effort to get on the bike, but once there I was fine. Rode the bike home, changed clothes, then Mark took me to the ER in the truck. Spent 30 or 40 minutes in the ER waiting room, then another hour in an ER bed until a doc came to see me. Well, not a doc. I was treated by a physicians assistant. An abrupt, condescending, PA who really annoyed me. She really did not listen to a thing I said. The PA left, and 20 minutes later I met the ortho. I got a good feeling from him and have decided to let him handle my treatment. They consensus from the docs is that I tore my ACL (anterior cruciate ligament). Just so you know this is not horrible, but it is bad. Some websites for info: http://www.sportsinjurybulletin.com/archive/0281a-acl-knee-injury.htm http://www.aclsolutions.com/ I have to call the doc's office on Tuesday to get my MRI scheduled. This will confirm the tear and see if it is complete. It will also determine if anything else in my knee is damaged. I am pretty much looking at surgery. It will be arthroscopic surgery so I won't have any big scars. They will take a dead guys donated ACL and replace mine. Kinda cool. In the mean time Mark has rigged up a way for me to carry my crutches and such on my bike. I did the first test of the system this morning. I made it to work on my motorcycle all by myself! Thank goodness, riding is like breathing to me. I would lose my mind if I couldn't ride. Dealing with my leg being stuck straight out and these damn crutches has not gone to well though. Seems like every five minutes I am presented with yet something else I can't do. The simplest things are now a huge production. Just getting up and going down the hall takes a great effort. Forget negotiating the stairs in and out of garage. On top of this there is a lot of muscle pain associated with learning the cructhes. My upper body hurts more than my knee. You would be amazed at how many muscles you use for crutches. The arms aren't even half of it. When this is over I am gonna have rock hard abs and serious right cross punch. This all has led to a great deal of frustration. Of course with me, frustration leads to cranky, bitchy, angry, demanding, and all around hell to be with. I will owe Mark a LOT of serious pampering when I get better.

Five days left until surgery day. Just because the earth has a sense of humor a heat wave is supposed to be here just in time for my surgery. Nothing like being miserable a nd hot as hell. So far this thing still sucks and I haven't found an upside. I am getting more and more nervous as it gets closer. My biggest fear is post surgical pain. I am going to discuss this with the doc at my pre-op visit Monday morning. I want to make sure I have a way to get a hold of him over the weekend in case I need something stronger for pain then this crappy vicodin. Vicodin just doesn't work all that well anymore. I think I have had it prescribed a few to many times in my life. Mom is coming up on Wednesday. I know there is a part of her that is going to enjoy taking care of her little girl. It took a while but I grew up and finally reached a point where I needed my Mom, but I didn't need her help anymore. I am sure that is bitter sweet for Moms. Proud because they raised a kid to be self sufficient, but crappy because their little ones don't need them to take care of them anymore. It wasn't until I moved 250 miles away that I realized I was a momma's girl. I am looking forward to Mom coming. I miss her cooking. Sometimes I hobble out to the living room to sit with Mark for a while. I get a little lonely by myself. Poor guy has got to be tired of taking care of me by now. I know I would be tired of it. I can be cranky.

WooHoo!! I am going to have a real pint glass from a real Irish pub. This just in from my good friend Charles' blog. He is currently in ireland somewhere having a damn good time. "I swiped a pint glass for my pal Julia, who wants gifts, but only if they are stolen. YAY!" More good stuff to add to my collection of stolen things from around the world. Last night sucked big time. First time since I was injured that it actually hurt. Kept waking up and was very unhappy and cranky. First time I took the drugs for pain and not for fun. I can't wait for my surgery to be over. Only eight days left. I just want to be done with this. I am really tired of it and have had enough.

Three and a half days until surgery. I had my pre-op doc visit today. All is well, surgery will happen on schedule. Physically I am doing well. Mentally, I am really done with this shit. I have had it. I haven't ridden in two weeks. Driving the truck sucks. Being in a car is like being in a concrete room with no windows, no doors, no light, no way out, and no connection to the machine or the outside world. Nothing exists outside your cold, dark, concrete enclosure. When you ride you see and feel everything. You are connected to your machine and the world around you. Instead of merely being along for the ride you control the ride. This all just sucks and I am done with it. Got so mad today that I tried to get up and walk. Nothing to slam reality inyour face like a good face plant in front of witnesses.

Everything is ordered and on schedule for Mark's birthday party this Sunday. I am looking forward to seeing people. I have been trapped in the house to long and it is driving me stir crazy. Can you say "cabin fever"? Yes, I thought you could. Had a creepy moment yesterday. I was laying around, like I do anything else anymore, and my knee turned into a little heater. You could feel the heat coming off of it. This creeped me out a little because it is a sign of infection. Worst case kind of thing they plant me in the hospital for two or three days and main line antibiotics. Anyway, I called the doc and they had me come in. On my way over I stopped for x-rays that I brought with me to the docs. Overall he is happy with the knee. Flexibility is good and the incision is healing nicely. He prescribed me a huge dose of antibiotics, 500mg, that I must take four times a day for two weeks. They are some impressive horse pills. Thank goodness they are capsules or they would be hell to swallow. I am going to scan and post up the x-rays after my next doc visit. They are the neatest thing. It is quite bizarre to stare at these x-rays, see the screws and the graft, and know that all that stuff is in me! Pain wise yesterday was good. I did not take any pain killers at all. Not bad considering where I was just a few days ago. Last night I had a bad moment. I hadn't realized how much this has come to annoy me emotionally. I was getting all wrapped, braced, and plugged into the ice machine for the night and I lost it. The fact that I just couldn't get up and go to the bathrooom, or fill my water bottle, or carry my own dinner, or any damn thing had reached a frustration high. The sheer effort involved in preparing to sleep became the straw that broke the camels back. Out of the blue I start bawling like a little girl. It totally snuck up on me and I was not prepared for it. Poor Mark, he is tired and has only been back from Chicago a few hours. Now he is stuck in a position where there is nothing he can do, nothing he can say, and nothing he does do or say is going to be the right thing. That poor man was damned no matter what. He took it like a champ though. I am very lucky to have him. Managed six hours straight of sleep though. I have come to the conclusion that there is nothing more glorious than being unconcious for multiple consecutive hours. Mom went home today. Physically and with Mark home I am ready for her to go. But I really was not ready for her to go. It was wonderful having her here taking care of me. She really took care of Mark too. It made everything so much easier having her here. I got a good Mom. Today has been a so so day. Periodically my knee, or shin, or thigh will start to throb like hell. It does that for about two to five minutes and is extremely painful. At one point today it started a constant and growing ache and I had to break down and take some pain killers. I am here to tell you kids, healing sucks. After Mom left I took my first unattended shower :o). I decided I stunk and couldn't stand it anymore. Since my injury I have not taken a shower without someone home just in case I fall or something. It is a bit annoying to know people are checking on you when you are doing something so basic and normal. It feels kind of like being imprisoned in a way. I was just going to do it. Then the visions of Mark calling, me not answering, then Mark calling me neighbor, then finding myself naked with my neighbor and her two kids looking at me in the shower started dancing in my head. So I called Mark and told him I was taking a shower and there was nothing he could do to stop me. He laughed, asked me to be careful, and told me to call him when I was done. I am looking forward to Monday. It will be sooooooooo wonderful to go back to work. It will make me feel human again. I will feel less helpless and less of a burden. I never thought sitting in cubicle would sound like heaven to me, but it does. I am also a little scared of Monday. It will be the first day of rehab. If you know what they do to you for this please let me know. It would be less creepy if I knew what to expect.

Then I did a little assisted walking up and down the hall way. I can't put full weight on it and I have to take small steps but it sure was nice. More importantly, I am clean!! I can't remember the last time a shower felt this good. I won't make it to work tomorrow. I am going to see how I do each day though. Maybe I can make it Wednesday. Mark has to leave tomorrow afternoon for Chicago. He will be back Thursday. I am not happy about it but there is nothing I can do about it. He isn't thrilled about it either. It is a business trip he can't get out of. My Mom is gonna stay with me until he gets home.

Today's weather forcast is for pain. Unending pain. I also have the greatest man in the world. He went out for a bit yesterday and came home with a DVD player for the bedroom and some DVD's. Yesterday was pure hell. The pain kept growing and growing. Drugs were worthless. At 7:oopm I had finally had enough and had Mark take me to the ER. The doc was a complete ass but my nurse was wonderful. They shot me full of dilaudid and fentanyl and sent me home with a script for Lorcet. I still didn't sleep through the night. Woke up every one to two hours. It was nice to sleep while it lasted though. No pain when I am asleep. I am going to miss Charles birthday party today :o( Happy 40th Birthday Charles!!

I have made yet another leap in my recovery. Today I no longer wear a brace. I am on one crutch instead of two. I was able to pedal all the way around on the stationary bike both forward and backward. Before all I could do was rock back and forth.

HUGE progress has been made!!! Today I put my foot on the peg and successfully shifted gears. I was also able to get my bike off of the kick stand and balance it. I can almost put it back on the kick stand but not quite. I think I might be able to ride this weekend!!!!! :o) I am also putting weight on the leg now and working on walking. The leg is still too weak to walk without my crutches though. Soon I will be walking though. Very, very, soon.

Friday night I learned a couple of valuable lessons. 1) Just because you can do something, does not mean you should do it. 2) Just because a little is a good thing, it does not mean a lot is better. I was at Charles celebration of being healthy and cancer free. It was nice to get out and see people. Anyway, so I am sitting there. It is so neat to sit normal with no brace. All of the sudden the muscle on the outside of my thigh informs me I have been over using it by having a big 'ol spasm. My leg jumped a good 8 inches off the chair, knee bent waaaay to fast. They had to peel me off the ceiling. 1) Just because you walk with one crutch does not mean you should do it every chance you get. 2) Just because you can walk a little, and a little is a good thing, does not mean doing it as much as possible is a good thing. I woke up Saturday morning with a double dose of misery. Calf and thigh muscles stiff, sore, spasms, and suffering for Fridays over doing it. To add to the funI got one of my throwing up, intolerable pain, vey dizzy migraines. So I got to spend my weekend in miserable pain. Sunday I felt like someone had pounded me and spent most of the day asleep recovering from the migraine. Physical therapy is going well. Every time I go in they add more work and it is harder. Today he even made me cry. It is a bit annoying sometimes. Everyone else in there are getting wonderful heat treatments, massages, and stuff. I am working my ass off and breaking a sweat. When do I get the massages? Every day at lunch I do my exercises. Every day I come home and do them again. They are not easy. It is hard work. This is not going to be over with fast enough as far as I am concerned.
